properties.name: 218 Flavours of Gelato @ La Casa Gelato
properties.description: Posted by TamiThere is always a lineup at Casa Gelato in the summertime, whether it\'s Saturday or Monday night. The staff are more than happy to give out samples of the flavours that interest you...and many will interest you. The standard vanilla, chocolate, strawberry is there...as well as unique items such as wasabi or even gorgonzola & pear. There are sorbettos and frozen yogurts, and flavours such as jackfruit, nut kalfi, lychee, green apple, rootbeer, death by mango, durian, vanilla lemon zest, and the list goes on. A single costs about 3 bucks; a double .

properties.name: Chinese Midnight Snack @ Landmark Hotpot Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Tami Said to be the first Chines hotpot restaurant in Vancouver, but whatever...Landmark is the best place to go to when you\'re still hungry and it\'s 10pm. It closes at 2am. It\'s known for its Hong Kong-style hotpots, with the cooking aparatus right at your table. Every time I visit the place we order the same items and they never fail to impress my tummy: the fresh seafood congee (a fresh plate of seafood arrives and you place the seafood into the congee to be cooked); sauteed pea shoots; minced garlic & honey spareribs; spicy seasoned salt encrusted small fish; spicy seasoned salt encrusted tofu; sauteed chinese pickles with peanuts, red/green peppers; and small medallions of chicken sauteed with red peppers, garlic, onions, dried spicy chili peppers. When you\'re stuffed, you\'ll be served a complimentary glass of "sour plum drink" to cleanse your palate. Landmark Hot Pot House 4023 Cambie Street, Vancouver (Phone: 604-872 2868)

properties.name: Chinese New Year Festival 2006
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing  Dr.Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden, Sunday, Jan. 29,2006 from 10:00am to 4:30pm, by donation. Chinese New Year Festival Celebrate the Year of the Dog with sound, color, and joy. The Garden’s plum blossom trees will be in full bloom signifying the return of spring. Chinatown and the Garden will be decorated for the biggest festival in the Chinese calendar. Activities include fortune telling, martial arts, calligraphy writing, storytelling, lucky red packets, and a special exhibition of traditional New Year arts by the Chinese Canadian Artists Federation. Watch for the big parade that winds through the streets of Chinatown around noon!

properties.name: Geography Building
properties.description: Posted by SanopupThis is probably the number one place on campus where I spent the most time in. I loafed a lot in the geography lounge reading, eating lunch, or napping. Once I had access to the computer lab starting in my 3rd year, I could often be found surfing the internet when there\'s no lab scheduled. The T1 connection sure beat the dial-up I used at my home. Courses I had here: Geography 101 (physical geography) Geography 207 (geography of ecosystems) Geography 317 (physical environment of BC) Geography 306 (geomorphology) Geography 372 (cartography) Geography 370 (GIS) Geography 472 (advanced cartography)

properties.name: Granville Island, Vancouver
properties.description: Posted by SaravcThe Dockside Brewing Company, in the Granville Island Hotel, features their own variety of Island brewed beers. Yummy! Also visit the Public Market, and Art School and local artist studios. From the outset of its redevelopment in the late 1970s, Granville Island has been a haven for the arts. All across the Island, former empty sheds have been reawakened as studios, stages, sets and scenery for art exhibits, theatrical plays, street performers, and music shows.

properties.name: Legendary Noodle
properties.description: Posted by Edbogus 4191 Main St., Vancouver, BCA window on the kitchen has seldom been so inspiring. Watch the chef de jour hack peices of dough into a boiling wok for thick stubby noodles, or roll his own green onion pancakes. While noodles and dumplings are the order of business here, side dishes like garlicky pea vines also excelled. A great culinary experience at a shockingly affordable price. "Legendary" may be the apt term to describe this dining experience. Noodles are created before your very eyes by an industrious gent who manipulates the dough at warp speed, spinning and twirling until lo, ropes of fresh pasta are produced. These are topped with full-flavor broths, enriched with cilantro, garlic-spiked lamb shanks, or barbecued pork, or eaten cold with chicken. Given the skill level, you\'d expect them to charge huge amounts for these noodles, but no—this place is very cheap" Conde Nast

properties.name: MacMillan Building
properties.description: Posted by SanopupOne of the more remote buildings on campus. The library upstairs contains mostly agriculture-related materials. The labour I had to endure to use the scanner in there... There\'s a nice lounge downstairs that was always scarcely occupied. It was [not] fun going (read: racing) from the geography building to here and then to the Buchanan buidling afterward, with 10 minutes between classes. Class I had here: Geography 204 (forest & agricultural climatology)

properties.name: Main Library
properties.description: Posted by SanopupOne of the famous landmarks on campus, along with the clock tower in the front garden. The whole building is something like 7 stories and contains materials covering many different fields. To access the geography stuff, one needed to climb down a narrow, one-man-width staircase to the underground levels, where it reeked of old books and somehting else. There is a relatively new computer lab in there on the upper level. Adjacent to the Main Library is a small map library. Student card pictures are taken here, and the line-up during peek hours can wind through two floors. Very fun to watch, provided you\'re not in the line yourself.

properties.name: Main and Broadway by Cub
properties.description: Posted by Baostar"Main and Broadway" was written by Lisa Marr about an encounter with a former boyfriend and his new girlfriend. The song title refers to the intersection of Main St. and E Broadway in Vancouver. You and her walking by You say "hello" so civilised Does she know you were my boy one time? So what am I supposed to say? "You\'re looking swell, have a nice day" Good to see she\'s prettier than me Things go on, I get confused I don\'t know how it feels to be... Anymore... (Chorus) Didn\'t know I missed you \'till today \'Cos I thought that love just went away Or at least I had it licked Rpt Chorus Didn\'t know I missed you \'till today... Love letters, broken lockets Dead flowers, candy boxes That\'s what you\'re left with when it\'s over It\'s over, it\'s over, it\'s over... Now I wonder what went wrong Why we didn\'t get along Nothing left but distance in your eyes There you go, hand in hand Leaving me alone to stand here, just Another stupid chump Fights of spite, and I could talk In the end that\'s what you got So what\'s the point of bothering at all? Rpt Chorus I was wrong... Rpt Chorus Didn\'t know I missed you \'till today... La la la la....

properties.name: Pat's Pub
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks  A little bit after moving to Vancouver (my tenure was rather brief) I was passed the reigns to booking Pat\'s Pub by the very personable and wonderful Mr. Chris Frey (he formerly of Radio Berlin, currently of The Book Of Lists), and spent the rest of the couple of months I did it baffled at how supportive people seemed of most of the shows that were put on, coming out just for the sake of seeing some music, and how immensely fun it was. It also helped that Pat\'s closed just after 12, leaving me time to go out afterwards and imbibe in a place where I had a little less responsibility. I saw many sweet bands before, during and after working here, including Radio Berlin, JWAB/Black Mountain (on my b-day!), The Battles, Orphan, Channels 3+4 (when Jesse dosed the crowd with a bunch of liquid THC he had somehow "come across" a day or so earlier), and uhh, countless other ones. Anyways, it was a spectacular time, and I trust that it\'s still the kick-ass place it was when Hana was booking it, too. I always thought that mural of Elvis on the stage-wall looked suspiciously like Steve Bays, in the Marnik days of HHH.

properties.name: Student Union Building (SUB)
properties.description: Posted by SanopupThis 3-level gaint complex is a great place to meet with friends for some quick bites or cramming. There\'s a small theatre that plays movies for , cafeteria, lounge, Internet kiosk, study area, ball rooms, shops, copy & print centre, arcade... The list can go on and on. The lobby and the side gallery often hold exhibitions or seasonal sales, and the Club Days are hosted here as well. I didn\'t hang out at the SUB too much but something could only be done there. The arcade downstairs taught me what DDR was (no, I never played it), and I could never forget the used bookstore where I got my astronomy text for 0 (usually 0 new or 0 used)!

properties.description: Posted by Edbogus Two room suites in the heart of of the West End at an affordable price. No typical hotel amenities except for secure parking and maid service. Highly recommended

properties.name: Tokyo Izakaya Eats & Cocktails @ Guu Otokomae
properties.description: Posted by Tami Although there are Guu\'s on Robson, Guu Otokomae in Gastown has a more open atmosphere and an amazing cocktail selection...more on that later. You\'ll find Guu Otokomae on the 2nd floor of its building, down Waterfront St between Steamworks and the steamclock. Guu Otokomae\'s menu serves homestyle Japanese "tapas" that is inexpensive, simple and tasty, such as yakionigiri (grilled riceballs), gindara (black cod with miso sauce), popeye salad (spinach, bacon, and chock full of veggies), and a poke-style marinated tuna with avocado and mango. The tapas shouldn\'t cost any more than .20. The cocktail menu is full of interesting things such as Rose Rum (with a base of the house rum where they infuse a real rose in rum), and the Snowflake (vodka, vanilla liquor, lemon, lychee ice balls).

properties.name: UBC Bookstore
properties.description: Posted by SanopupThis is where most people get their textbooks and should be avoided during the first two weeks of each term if possible. It\'s a great place to relax otherwise. I used to spend hours every week in there looking at pretty much everything: art supplies, stationary, books on web design, natural sciences, astronomy, music, fine arts, literature. There\'s lots of computer stuff, but I wasn\'t into technology much at that time so I never paid attention. I held my Windows 95 laptop dearly up until entering 3rd year, if my memory serves me right.
